newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: S.Korea's April note default ratio hits 15-yr high.
newsitem.headline: S.Korea's April note default ratio hits 15-yr high.

text.p: The ratio of South Korea's defaults on notes hit a 15-year high of 0.25 percent in April, the central Bank of Korea said on Thursday.
"This is the highest monthly figure in the last 15 years," a central bank official told Reuters.
This is compared with 0.15 percent in the same month a year ago and 0.24 percent in March, the bank said in a statement.
The notes would include such debts as promissory notes and bank cheques.
It said the rise was largely due to the defaults by affiliate companies of financially troubled groups such as Hanbo, Sammi and Jinro.
The central bank said 1.89 trillion won worth of notes were not honoured in April out of a total 769.4 trillion won that should have been repaid.
The number of defaulting companies increased to 1,318 in April, against 936 a year ago and 1,268 in March, it said.
